title: 107_hr5223
content: The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. It includes an amendment to Title 31. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" includes an amendment to Title 31, specifically adding a new section for continuing appropriations in case regular appropriation bills are not passed before the fiscal year begins. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" includes provisions for continuing appropriations at a rate of operations not exceeding 75 percent of the previous fiscal year's funding levels. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" allows for funding at a rate not exceeding 75 percent of the previous fiscal year's levels, with specific criteria for determining funding rates during a lapse in appropriations. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" allows funding up to 75% of the previous fiscal year's levels during a lapse in appropriations, with specific criteria for determining funding rates. Appropriations for projects or activities are subject to terms and conditions from the preceding fiscal year. The section covers obligations and expenditures for projects or activities during a fiscal year. Expenditures must be charged to the appropriate funding source when a regular appropriation bill becomes law. This section does not apply if another law provides funding or prohibits appropriations for the project or activity. The term 'regular appropriation bill' refers to annual bills that allocate funds for various categories of projects and activities, including agriculture, rural development, defense, and government operations in the District of Columbia. This section does not apply if another law prohibits funding for a specific project or activity. The curr_chunk discusses various activities chargeable against District revenues, including departments like Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, Housing and Urban Development, Energy and water development, Foreign assistance, Interior, Military construction, Transportation, Treasury Department, Postal Service, Executive Office of the President, and legislative branch. A clerical amendment is also mentioned in the text. The analysis of chapter 13 of title 31, United States Code, is amended by inserting a new item after section 1310. The amendments made by this section do not affect government obligations mandated by other laws, including Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid. The amendments in this Act will apply to fiscal years starting from 2003 and will expire 3 years after the Act's enactment.
